message.content: This question requires understanding of the physical properties of water. When water is bubbling, it indicates that there is intense heat causing the water to reach its boiling point and form bubbles of water vapor. Option (B) is incorrect because if the water is bubbling, it is not likely to be cool. Option (C) is incorrect because melting refers to a phase change from solid to liquid, not bubbling. Option (D) is unrelated to bubbling and refers to the ease of transporting water, which is not relevant to its bubbling characteristic.

To answer this question, we need basic knowledge about the behavior of water when it bubbles. When water is bubbling, it is likely to have intense heat. This is because bubbles form due to the boiling of water, which occurs when it reaches its boiling point and turns into vapor. Option (B) is incorrect because cool water does not bubble, it is usually calm and still. Option (C) is incorrect because melting refers to a solid turning into a liquid, not a liquid turning into a gas. Option (D) is unrelated to the bubbling of water.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the properties of water and the process of boiling. When water is bubbling, it means that it is boiling. Boiling occurs when the temperature of the water reaches its boiling point, which is 100 degrees Celsius or 212 degrees Fahrenheit. This indicates that the water is heated and has an intense heat characteristic. Option (B) is incorrect because cool water does not bubble, it needs to be heated to reach its boiling point. Option (C) is incorrect because melted water would be in a liquid form and typically does not bubble unless it is heated beyond its boiling point. Option (D) is unrelated to the bubbling characteristic of water.
